instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance in predicting anthocyanin concentration, pH index, and sugar content in whole grape berries?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the SVR model in predicting anthocyanin concentration, pH index, and sugar content in whole grape berries was R-2 (R-squared).

instruction: How were the machine learning models trained, validated, and tested in the study evaluating the performance of the SVR model in predicting anthocyanin concentration, pH index, and sugar content in whole grape berries using spectroscopic measurements?
Output: In the study, the machine learning models were trained, validated, and tested using different combinations of Touriga Franca (TF) vintage samples. The TF vintage samples from 2012-2015 were independently used to train, validate, and test the SVR methodology. The models were trained and tested with different combinations of TF vintages to assess the performance differences under wider and more variable datasets. The varieties that were not employed in the model training and validation (Touriga Nacional and Tinta Barroca) were used to test the generalization ability of the SVR approach. Each case was tested using an external independent set of data that was not included in the model training or validation steps.

instruction: How does the performance of the SVR model with a Gaussian radial basis kernel compare to traditional methods in predicting anthocyanin concentration, pH index, and sugar content in whole grape berries using spectroscopic measurements obtained in reflectance mode?
Output: The performance of the SVR model with a Gaussian radial basis kernel in predicting anthocyanin concentration, pH index, and sugar content in whole grape berries using spectroscopic measurements obtained in reflectance mode is reported to be good overall. The model achieved R-2 values of 0.89, 0.81, and 0.90 for anthocyanin concentration, pH index, and sugar content, respectively. The root mean square error (RMSE) values were 35.6 mgL(-1), 0.25, and 3.19 degrees Brix for the respective parameters. These results indicate that the SVR model outperforms traditional methods and improves upon the state-of-the-art results for external test sets. The model also demonstrates a generalization capacity over different grape varieties and harvest years, making it a competitive and cost-effective approach compared to models from other authors.
